## Lecture 5

## CT Generated by Pure Injectives

### Technique: Tor-torsion Theory

A tor-torsion theory induces a cotorsion theory with good proeprty.

{% def %}
Say $(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{B})$ consists of a tor-torsion theory, provided

$$\begin{equation}
\mathcal{A}^âŠº := \ker \mathrm{Tor}(\mathcal{A}, -) = \mathcal{B}; \quad {}^âŠº\mathcal{B} := \ker \mathrm{Tor}(-, \mathcal{B}) = \mathcal{A}.
\end{equation}$$

{% enddef %}

{% pro %}
Show that both $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ are closed under summands, extensions, and filtered colimits.

- In general, the left derives of the left adjoint commutes with filtered colimits.

{% endpro %}

The following lemma ***embeds*** the tor-torsion theory into general cotorsion theory.

{% lem %}
For any $X âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _R$ and $Y âˆˆ ğŒğ¨ğ _{R^{\mathrm{op}}}$, $\mathrm{Ext}^1(X,Y^+) =0$ **iff** $\mathrm{Tor}_1(X,Y) = 0$.

{% pf %}
Note that $(-)^+$ preserves and reflects exactness and zero-objects.

$$\begin{equation}
\mathrm{Ext}^1(X, Y^+) = H^1((P(X), Y^+)) â‰ƒ (H^1(P(X) âŠ— Y))^+ = \mathrm{Tor}_1(X, Y)^+.
\end{equation}$$
{% endpf %}

{% endlem %}

{% ex %}
$(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , \mathcal{A})$ and $(\mathcal{A}, ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ )$ are tor-torsion theories. Hence $(ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ , ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚ )$ is a cotorsion theory. $ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚$ is known as *Enoch's cotorsion module*.

$$\begin{equation}
\mathcal{A}^+ âŠ† \text{Pure Injective} âŠ† ğ…ğ¥ğšğ­ ^âŸ‚.
\end{equation}$$

{% endex %}

{% ex %}
(Torsion-free module). Recall that

$$\begin{equation}
0 â†’ \mathrm{Tor}_1(X, R/(r)) â†’ X âŠ— (r) â†’ X â†’ X âŠ— R/(r) â†’ 0.
\end{equation}$$

If $R$ has no zero-divisor, then $\mathrm{Tor}_1(X, R/(r)) = \{xr = 0 âˆ£ x âˆˆ X\}$ is a subgroup. If $R$ is commutative domain with factional field $K$, then

$$\begin{equation}
\mathrm{Tor}_1(X,K/R) = \varinjlim_{r âˆˆ R âˆ– \{0\}} \! \!\! ^{fil} \ \ \mathrm{Tor}(X,R/(r)) = \text{torsion subgrp of } \ X.
\end{equation}$$

A torsion-free tor-torsion theory (for general rings) is cogenerated by cyclic modules, i.e.,

$$\begin{equation}
ğ“ğ… = {}^âŠº ğ‚ğ²ğœğ¥ğ¢ğœ = {}^âŸ‚ \{(R/(r))^+ : r âˆˆ R\}.
\end{equation}$$
